LayoutNode.Content: Echo Dot (2nd Generation) -Smart speaker with Alexa -White
LayoutNode.SRC: Echo Dot (2nd Generation) - Smart speaker with Alexa - White

LayoutNode.Content: Would 3 2nd gen echo dots in one 1000 square foot home sync with eachother or would there be issues? Example, 1 order of pizza might turn into 3. asked on September 14, 2016
LayoutNode.SRC:
Would 3 2nd gen echo dots in one 1000 square foot home sync with eachother or would there be issues? Example, 1 order of pizza might turn into 3.Would 3 2nd gen echo dots in one 1000 square foot home sync with eachother or would there be issues? Example, 1 order of pizza might turn into 3.

asked on September 14, 2016

LayoutNode.Content: The dot and echo do not sync with each other, they operate independently which is a disappointment if you expect to use one or the other to be able to play music or features in different parts of the house, that will not happen. Furthermore, supposedly you can sync one with the other via bluetooth, but try doing that when they are separated by several rooms. I think Amazon really missed the boat on this one when they have failed to allow echo or a chosen dot to act as a master for all the others. It does work very well through a power amp to play thru speakers connected to the amp as you would say bose acousimass speakers. And the dot works just as the echo does. But the inability to be able to have dots and echo play in tandem thought the house is a major failure - as far as we're concerned. reader · October 24, 2016 31 of 41 found this helpful. Do you? Yes No

Comment

LayoutNode.Content: You can play music to all your alexia devices at the same time, you have to go into groups and start the all rooms group I believe it’s called normally. I renamed mine house. So when I start any music I add saying in the house group and the music will play from all my devices at the same time with the same music I asked to be played
LayoutNode.SRC: You can play music to all your alexia devices at the same time, you have to go into groups and start the all rooms group I believe it’s called normally. I renamed mine house. So when I start any music I add saying in the house group and the music will play from all my devices at the same time with the same music I asked to be played You can play music to all your alexia devices at the same time, you have to go into groups and start the all rooms group I believe it’s called normally. I renamed mine house. So when I start any music I add saying in the house group and the music will play from all my devices at the same time with the same music I asked to be played

LayoutNode.Content: GhostriderGale · October 2, 2018 | Report abuse You can play the same music on all your echo devices at the dame time. Set up play on all. I can walk around my house and all 3 are playing the same music. I love it.
LayoutNode.SRC: GhostriderGale · October 2, 2018 | Report abuse You can play the same music on all your echo devices at the dame time. Set up play on all. I can walk around my house and all 3 are playing the same music. I love it.

LayoutNode.Content: B. Marcus · October 2, 2018 | Report abuse Multi room music does not work if your Echo Dots are connected to Bluetooth speakers. It initiates a disconnect from the Bluetooth speakers reverting to source (Dot) speaker. This is incredibly disappointing as the Dot speakers do not provide good sound quality for listening to music. I purchased my Dots for the sole purpose that they could connect to external speakers via either Bluetooth or cable. I would love to have MultiRoom music function with the great sound that my Bluetooth speakers put out, however, I have no interest in MultiRoom Echo Dot metallic sound. It seems ridiculous to me that there is not MultiRoom functionality while utilizing one of the main features (connectivity to external speakers) promoted for the Echo Dot when it was introduced.

LayoutNode.Content: S. Fox · July 16, 2018 | Report abuse I have no issue playing different music. Initially it says it won’t but then it still does

LayoutNode.Content: Christopher L · July 10, 2018 | Report abuse This is no longer true. You can now group your devices and ask Alexa to play whatever on a specific group. I simply created a group called everywhere, with all of my echo and dot devices in that group so I can simply say something like "play Moana everywhere" and my toddler is in musical heaven with all devices playing back in perfect unison.
LayoutNode.SRC: Christopher L · July 10, 2018 | Report abuse This is no longer true. You can now group your devices and ask Alexa to play whatever on a specific group. I simply created a group called everywhere, with all of my echo and dot devices in that group so I can simply say something like "play Moana everywhere" and my toddler is in musical heaven with all devices playing back in perfect unison. This is no longer true. You can now group your devices and ask Alexa to play whatever on a specific group. I simply created a group called everywhere, with all of my echo and dot devices in that group so I can simply say something like "play Moana everywhere" and my toddler is in musical heaven with all devices playing back in perfect unison.

LayoutNode.Content: Jessica M. · May 6, 2018 | Report abuse I have an Echo and an Echo dot and they are set up to play the same thing. I just ask Alexa to play everywhere.

LayoutNode.Content: Deberra Engelke · March 2, 2018 | Report abuse This is incorrect. I have an echo and an echo dot, both of which can sync together and play music from my Spotify, iHeart or pandora account. And when I say Alexa, whatever one I’m closest to, answers, the most common reason why your echo devices won’t sync together to play music is because there is an issue with your internet router settings.

And when I say Alexa, whatever one I’m closest to, answers, the most common reason why your echo devices won’t sync together to play music is because there is an issue with your internet router settings.
